Award.AwardTitle: Conference Support for 2016 North American Power Symposium, Denver, Colorado, September 18 - 20, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal requests funding to subsidize student-related travel expenses incurred by US university students attending the 2016 edition of the annual North American Power Symposium (NAPS). NAPS 2016 will be hosted by the University of Denver in Denver, CO, from September 18 to September 20, 2016. NAPS is a nonprofit event with technical sponsorship from the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) and is aimed primarily at a student audience. Traditionally, the overwhelming majority of papers in NAPS are presented by students. NAPS has been supported by the National Science Foundation in the past, which has positively influenced student participation. Based on the attendance trend from previous years, it is anticipated that the subsidy provided through this grant can significantly increase the number of students participating in NAPS in this year as well. In addition to providing subsidized accommodation for students, the organizers' efforts to foster and encourage student participation include a comprehensive student program, tours of nearby attractions, and a student paper competition with awards. Moreover, measures will be taken to encourage participation of women and underrepresented minorities in NAPS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award of $15,000 from NSF’s EPCN (Energy, Power, Control and Networks) program was used to partially subsidize student-related expenses (e.g., travel, per diem, registration, and accommodation) for US students attending the 48th North American Power Symposium (NAPS), which was held at Denver, Colorado, September 18 - 20, 2016. This precious funding support helped us successfully host the conference with an excellent student program. NAPS is aimed primarily at a student audience with an overwhelming majority of papers being presented by students. This NSF support has positively influenced student participation. In addition to providing subsidized accommodation for registered students, this includes a comprehensive student program, tours of attractions of the area, and a student paper contest. Participation of women and minorities are encouraged to attend NAPS. 

NAPS 2016 was unique in its focus on students preparing and presenting technical papers. The NSF award facilitated graduate students’ interaction with faculty and industry attendees to receive feedback on their research work. Research topics covered in the Symposium included: Microgrids and Advanced Distribution, Power System Operation and Control, Demand Response, Renewables, Power System Analysis, Intelligent Grid, Communications and Cybersecurity, Power Electronics. High quality publications from the graduate students in the Power and Energy field are made possible by the NSF award. Specifically, NAPS 2016 included 2 plenary sessions, 20 paper sessions and 1 poster presentation session. 172 papers are presented and all those presented papers are now published in the IEEE Explorer database.
